column1: # Create a new line for each processor type.

All calculations were performed on my laptop running an Intel Core i5 processor.
LSER parameters were predicted on the UFZ-LSER website.
# List all major software packages used and their versions.
# Create a new line for each software.
# State which method category your prediction method is better described as:
# Level of details should be roughly equivalent to that used in a publication.
# Please list out the method details of predictions for each solvent pair considered.
# Please include the values of key parameters with units.
# Please explain how statistical uncertainties were estimated.
# Please report SMILES strings and populations of all the microstates used in calculations in this section.
# Use as many lines of text as you need.
# All text following the 'Method:' keyword will be regarded as part of your free text methods description.
# Important: Please do not use phrases which are identical to the section headers of logD data. For example do not use "Octanol-water predictions:"
# but use "Octanol-water predictions" instead (without the colon) or any other form. See example below.
This work follows our SAMPL6 entry
were predicted from the provided smiles on the UFZ-LSER website (https://www.ufz.de/index.php?en=31698&contentonly=1&m=0&lserd_data[mvc]=Public/start).
Once Abraham solute descriptors were predicted for the SAMPL8 neutral reference molecules
existing LSER correlations were used to predict logP for all of the binary systems of interest.
Correlations for MEK and TBME with water assumed the organic-solvent phase was dry. For the other cases
the organic-solvent was saturated with water. Cyclohexane/DMF were assumed pure solvents.
We then corrected the predicted logP values involving water to obtain logD using the experimental pKa values
# All submissions must either be ranked or non-ranked.

column2: but you can turn in as many nonranked submissions as you want (we will still run analysis on them).
